reviews.review_text: This is incredibly hard for me to do, but I'm giving this game a negative review. I don't think I've ever been emotionally involved in a game more than in Ori and the Blind Forest, and it's been a real pleasure to play it again in the Definitive Edition, the feels are still there. This game has everything for it, from gorgeous graphics, to insanely good music and addictive gameplay with a great difficulty curve as well as clever level design, and a nice story with adorable characters.  The new features in the Definite Edition are really nice, the difficulty settings let everyone enjoy the game the way they want, teleporting made me more motivated to find all secrets, the two new zones are really fun to explore, the new music is really pleasant to listen to, and being able to come back to the Ginso Tree and Forlorn Ruins if we forgot to get some collectibles is awesome, as well as being able to keep playing on a save file even after completing the game.  I'd also like to mention how the game runs way better than the original Ori and the Blind Forest, the problem of visuals and sound not being in sync during cutscenes isn't there anymore in the Definitive Edition, and some laggy areas of the original doesn't anymore, which is perfect if you don't have a beast of a computer.  So yeah, I really love this game, and I HIGHLY recommend anyone to play it. Unless you really have a passionate hate towards Metroidvanias, I'm pretty sure you'll love Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition.

Keep in mind that I haven't really played 2D Sidescrolling MetroidVania platforming games, or whatever genre this is.  My thoughts on this game - mixed, but generally positive  Starting the game you are blasted by a beautiful soundtrack which stays that way throughout the game. Further, the art-style is gorgeous to look at. It's a charming game.  The opening cinematic story sections are heartfelt and get you motivated to keep playing the game as it does have an air of mystery about it. Consider the world of Avatar and the way that world had an atmosphere of 'magic' about it - the viewer, or player in this case, wanting to immerse themselves in that world - this game achieves that.  Playing through as Ori to restore life to the forest you will go through many areas and mazes, conquer many traps and upgrade your abilities over time as well as even hunt and locate secrets to further boost those upgrades. The upgrades themselves exist on 3 'trees' where, as you obtain skill points through combat and secret boosts you can adavnce along any and all increasing your attack damage, gaining additional mid-air jumps, increasing the effect of life restoration, revealing some secrets on the map, and so on. The secrets are not too out of the way and over the course of the game I didn't need to 'grind' for skill points which is good. It's a very casual game as without necessarily intending to, I found that I located most of the secrets. Some I did want to find just because I wanted to master my abilities which also works to the game's advantage. The story is pleasant and magical and the tense moments are just that.  However. (Keep in mind this is my first venture into these types of games)   Controls.  Mouse and keyboard - you will be jumping a LOT. Be prepared for aching fingers and you might need a thimble for your thumb on the spacebar. At one point I picked up my controller because of this, but found I had to move BACK to mouse and keyboard because of the rather silly way in which some abilities are implemented and not being particularly suited to the D-Pad of a controller. (I didn't use sticks as I would find that I would be going up or down unintentionally).  There also appears to be a bug for PC where some abilities do not even work (ones obtained from skill trees). But I could complete the game without them anyway.    Level Design.  Maybe I'm impatient, maybe I'm easily frustrated, but some levels and their designs are infuriating. WHen you have so many control systems and abilities to juggle the level design can be very tricky to navigate without some abilities getting in the way or not working necessarily as intended.  As someone with a visual impairment, sometimes the art-style to the game, while fantastic, was a drawback because it made seeing where I could stand and where I could not quite hard leading to many deaths on my part. Then there are the tense climax/chase moments in the game. These should be fast, exciting, but ultimately just turn into trial and error 50, 100-attempt sections that by the end you have lost all your excitement and just want to get the section over with.  Most of the game is relatively straight-forward however and was only really frustrating to me outside of the things I mentioned already when I just found controls, level design, or Ori's movement to be unintutive or temperamental.  Having said this, overall I would recommend the game, it's a charming experience and I imagine would be much more enjoyable to those more experienced with 2D side-scrolling platformers. As my first step into the genre, I'd say it was worth the time and money, although it isn't too long - maybe pick it up when it's on sale. Worth a second play-through, perhaps not for me. But I will be picking up that soundtrack, and that opening will probably stay with me a good while.

An expanded version of one of the best platformers out there.  The Ori-ginal is great by itself. It has some of the most fluid, fun controls and challenges of any game I've played, and it's clear from the start that the people of Moon Studios perfectly understood what they were doing, because everything works masterfully! Simply moving around feels great, and combined with creative environments and obstacles, it adds up to a kind of platforming brilliance that you don't see very often. Despite the structure of the game, I'd argue that it's more Rayman than Metroid, though I strongly recommend it to pretty much anyone who enjoy sidescrollers. It's a game that keeps getting better with every new challenge and every new ability, most of which only enhance the platforming (the bash ability changes everything). It also has the best quicksaving system I've ever seen.  All of it is wrapped up in a fantastic presentation. The art is detailed and gorgeous, the soundtrack is dramatic and unforgettable, and both compliment each other perfectly, as well as the grand, poetic storytelling that goes all out to make the world feel gigantic and ancient. It seems like the developers only took lessons from the best of the best, and nothing feels underwhelming, cut short or left out in any way. It's all extremely polished.  It's pretty weird that this Definitive Edition isn't just an update to the original version, because now that game is just taking up space on the store and in my library. There doesn't seem to be any reason to buy it when the DE is the same thing + new levels, new abilities, difficulty settings, fast travel options and full backtracking support (although more graphical options would've been nice as well). Having beaten the old version, all these additions were very notable, very early on, and they only serve to make the game more exciting than ever.  If you like magic, fun, challenge and feeling emotions, you should pick this up. There has never been a better time to do so.

Probably the best platformer on a PC ever. Not only is this game gorgeous articistically, and in particular its soundtrack, it also challenges you. Whether you're playing for 100% completion, deathless victory, stressing through a 3-hour speedrun or just hopping around for your first time, this game provides some unique challenges that flow along beautiful gameplay. This is definitely the best non-Mario platforming game, ever. Get it and play through at least once in your life.  As far as the Definitive Edition versus the Original, the Definitive Edition offers 2 new abilities which only get truly utilized in one major new area on the map. Without any spoilers, is based around a Naru-centric story which is short but sweet. It can be confusing since rather than adding new challenges in other areas of the map, tney just forced you to get the new abilities to unlock some older ones. The greatest part is that you can get back into all the areas and use waypoints to teleport. This is nice and saves time, though if you're trying to collect all the secrets, you'll still be hoofing through areas a second time when you get triple and charge jumps. It could just be me, but I noticed some lag on the water escape which I never had on the original and shouldn't ever really have. Furthermore, I noticed Steam failed to register my achievements after a while.  In summary, I loved this game so much that quite honestly I didn't mind any of the shortcomings with the Definitive Edition-specific content, But to be clear, the definitive edition doesn't really add much of anything worthwhile. If you've never played through Ori and Blind Forest, do it. It is fantastic. If you have but are wondering if the Definitive Edition is worth getting... I'd say only as an excuse to play through it again. Keep in mind, that like most platformers, replay value is limited. You can aim for achievements, but despite my love i probably won't play it again for 6 months to a year and soonest. Ori and the Blind Forest is fantastic, and plays really well on both Xbox and Steam controllers, but can be extra challenging on a keyboard thanks to the eventual use of 8 buttons/keys for different purposes. No matter what, this game is worth playing once though. And possibly obsessing over it's soundtrack afterwards. The Definitive Edition could be worth skipping, but let's all just hope we eventually get an Ori sequal at some point.

It was a conflicting surprise to see Ori get a rather costly update (if you didn't buy it when it was down to 25%). Compared to the original game it has two new powerups, reworked ability system and an extra area you can find. The most important update would be the removal of area restriction; in the old version you couldn't access certain story-heavy areas after you'd cleared them story-wise. This was a bane for the 100%'ers who didn't do it right on the spot.   Nevertheless, this game.. this f*cking game. It's beautiful. It's grand. As a platformer it has everything from enticing atmosphere, immersive surroundings and magnificent music to excellent controllability and easy-to-understand game mechanics. It's got an unique system called Bash, which is an ability you open during the first third. It alone makes you feel like a fast and nimble spirit creature speeding across the poisoned forest.   The character grows stronger and faster and the very scenery feels alive by adding permanent (positive) changes on the world as you progress the story. Though it's for only 4-6 hours, every hour feels twice the amount. It's that kind of game that sticks with you as a positive memory. It's a game I'd want my children to play if I ever conceived any.  Don't be afraid to pay the full price. Please support the people that made this game. It's worth every penny.

I've finished this game twice so far and let me tell you this; if you're a fan of good and fluid platforming like Super Meat Boy (or the old days of 2D Super Mario on the SNES or NES), this game deserves a spot in your library without a doubt. It has one of the best platforming in years I'd wager. Along with level designs that make great use of Ori's abilities (and how well animated Ori is), moving around and exploring have never felt more satisfying.  However, and this is entirely my opinion, if you're feeling for a more Metroidvania game with a fleshed out combat system or deeper RPG mechanics, this game does neither of those. Granted, the combat mechanic fulfills its purpose, but it can be pretty mindless as your means of offense is to only repeatedly press a button to kill your enemies with little to no strategy as your projectiles automatically homes onto an enemy, and sometimes pulling off a charged attack when need be. Don't let me fool you though, this game does offer a variety of ways to finish off your enemies by using the environment to your advantage. Additionally, you'll unlock more abilities to maneuver around the gorgeous world, allowing exploration to be fun, rewarding and less repetitive. The light RPG mechanic, albeit simplistic, works wondefully well as the abilities and upgrades you unlock have a great synergy with one another and are well balanced, making it so that there's no ability or upgrade that is outright useless or overpowered. This game's story is the weakest link, but if anything, it gives you just the right amount of motivation to continue playing while you're engrossed by the beautiful soundtrack, only to realize that you've already reached the end.   All in all, it's a good game and I enjoyed it thoroughly so play it now, you dork.

This game delivers in terms of art and music. Some of the most beautiful graphics and art I've seen in a game, and the accompanying score is some of the best music I've heard written for a game resulting in a beautiful game with absolutely gorgeous music. The mechanics of the game is implemented pretty nicely. You jump through the air, jump off of projectiles before travelling through a tunnel of spikes. Everything becomes fluid and multiple skills are used in succession. This game has a tonne of secrets which requires a lot of exploring (and backtracking which can get annoying). Numerous skills (with Bash being a favourite of mine) can be obtained and need to be used in order to beat a lot of the areas. Despite all this, there are some things that are left to be desired. The difficulty spike means that the game can get difficult quicker than other games like this, which will test one's patience. The story, while emotional, is not anything special. The combat isn't as complex and developed (such as the combat system in Dust), instead focusing on platforming and puzzles (with a few time-trials). This means that if your looking for a tear-jerking story and/or intense action, you'll be disappointed.  If you want a story-rich game or a combat intensive game, this probably isn't the game you're looking for. However, if you want a game that looks stunning, has incredible music and/or challenging platforming, this is the game you're looking for.

Original Ori Review: First Edition (I have 47+ hours on this edition) This is one of those games that deserve the 'Perfect Game' category. Perfect balance between action, puzzles, challenges and rewarding cutscenes that will keep you at the edge of the seat. You will end this game with a smile on your face and quite possible, tears. Congratulations to the devs and thanks for creating a game that can be called without any doubt, a masterpiece. I have to make a special mention to the Music, since it is a great part of the experience.  Gameplay 10/10 Graphics 10/10 Music 10/10  About Definitive Edition: Definitive Edition adds background story on Naru and a new map. Both additions have the same level of quality as the original game. Also there are new powers, fast travelling between zones and difficulty levels, which is great because now my 5 yo kid can play the game by himself in the easy difficulty.  Conclusion: DE is great for re-playing the entire game, and the new songs in the soundtrack are really *really* good. Upgrading worths every penny.  *Edit 11/23: Nominating this game for “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Award : )

Absolutely incredible game in every sense of the word. The original was a masterpiece, and the Definitive Edition was even more so. Truly an amazing game.   The art design and overall mood of the game is breathtaking. It's very visually appealing, with unique graphics and beautiful artwork. The moods it creates resonate with the player very well, and it is very immersive.   The music is simply spectacular. Before I even owned the game I listened to the music on repeat for days, I was captivated. The music adds to the mood making it at times feel lighthearted, and other times feel mysterious and mystical. Truly amazing soundtrack and overall sound design.  The gameplay, similarly, is very rewarding and thrilling. While it is a 2D platformer, there are numerous movement abilities you can gain through playing that allow you to control Ori in all sorts of ways. While the game is difficult, it is not frustrating. You have to be good with a new ability to use it to its fullest potential, and you have to really think about what you are doing at times. The gameplay is very interactive, and the combat (while slightly repetitive) is very fun as well. Once you get bash, a whole WORLD of possibilities opens up for you.  Lastly, the story is very immersive and full of emotion. The studio really did a wonderful job of conveying emotion and atmosphere in this game with little dialogue, and it is beautifully done. The characters are fun and dynamic, and really add a lot to the game.  Overall, I cannot recommend this game enough to anyone and everyone. It is truly a masterpiece. I've spent many hours playing this game and I have no plans to stop now. If you love video games at all, you're truly missing out by not playing this game.

Everyone seems to love this game, but it just didn't come together into an enjoyable package for me.  The introductory sequence (about 20 minutes or so) made a very poor first impression. The movement during the 'interactive' opening is painfully slow, and the attempts to get me emotionally attached to the characters were not effective.   When one of the characters dies, you are treated to flashbacks of the two characters' key moments together, things that you actually just did 3 minutes prior! These types of flashback scenes work 40 hours into an RPG, where you do get the feeling of 'old friends'. They don't work in the first 20 minutes.   I stopped caring about the story here at the beginning, and nothing thereafter made me re-engage.  The few characters who speak in this game use a synthetic language. The little sprite that follows you around is cute, and has a lot of variety in his/her different sounds. The problem is the deep-voiced narrator. From the intonation of his phrases to the individual pronunciation of syllables, he sounds exactly like Jabba the Hutt. No joke, it is either an intentional homage or the creators were unaware of the influence of Return of the Jedi when they thought they were creating original sounds. It is very distracting and you can't take anything he says seriously.  The combat is unsatisfying and consists primarily of mashing a single attack button when you are somewhat near an enemy. This is because attacks auto-target foes; you don't even have to be facing them. Fortunately combat is not a major part of the game.  The music seems good at first, but most zones are quite large, with the corresponding music tracks on a relatively short loop, and they get old fast. The artwork and animations are beautiful, no problem there.  Don't let the colorful palette and cute characters fool you; a handful of sequences are extraordinarily difficult. These catch you off guard because the majority of the game is very forgiving as far as the basic platforming and combat goes. Then every so often (  the major story events and the end-game sequence  ) you will hit sections where the spikes in the challenge level are abrupt and extreme, where you will be required to exhibit near-perfect timing and repeat long sections over and over until you get everything right. The game was reminiscent of something like Super Meat Boy at these times. I have a hunch that many people enjoyed the game up until   the water tree section  , and that was the end for them.  Platforming and exploration follow the Metroidvania style where you find power-ups that expand your techniques for moving about the world. But a lot of the treasures you can backtrack to get aren't really worth it (too many of them are just experience globes) and there is really only one main path forward as you gain each new ability.  There are some cool stages in this game, like the one where certain parts of the floor and walls will rotate the orientation of your directional movement and jumps. It's hard to explain and best experienced on your own. That is, if you can make it past   the water tree part  . :)

I'm afraid my overall experience with the game has been far too negative to warrant a positive review.  First off: the good. - Graphic: The game is visually stunning, smooth and very pleasant to look at. - Sound: The soundtrack is spot on and all audio effects are great.  The bad. - Story: For what i've played, the story of the game is ridiculously bland. [Minor Story Spoiler]   You start off as a white leaf in a stormy night, you fall off and you turn into a child. A forest creature takes care of you. You see the pair eating fruits until nearby trees run out, your newfound mother dies of hunger just as you bring home enough fruits for a few days, so you depart. You die, but by dying you are brought back to life because the ancient tree you initially fell from has put all its hope into you. Eventually you reach the tree but a giant black bird decided to steal a glowing orb inside the tree and threw it away, now your job is to find three stones and bring them to three different places to restore order to the forest.   Now, in my eyes this is a very, very boring storyline that exists mainly to justify your adventures. If you disagree, which is absolutely fine, try to tell any friend or person you know what the game's story is without having them laugh or be left extremely confused.  - Gameplay: Frustrating and tedious, put shortly. The game feels like a mix of Super Meat Boy and Metroid, as in you roam around from point to point across multiple obstacles with a certain degree of difficulty involved, while you will eventually find statues that give you additional abilities and with a bunch of side pickups if you're interested to hunt for them.  Now, unlike SMB and metroid, Ori and the Blind Forest doesn't do a great job at telling you what or where are threats; this is caused by graphical clutter (as you may find enemies completely covered by the foreground) or by using different colors: initially purple means bad, which makes sense and helps recognize threats immediatly. Eventually you may find differently colored threats that are hard to recognize quickly (mostly due to the graphical clutter, again).  So you died...it will happen, especially as there are a few areas where the developers want you to die at least that one time, and you'll find yourself back to your save point. Where is the save point? It's wherever you want! You're in charge of placing checkpoints! While this seems like a great design choice at first, it turns out to be fairly tedious after a while mainly because you do not know what you will face next. To create a checkpoint you'll need one unit of energy, which can be found in blue crystals scattered around the scenery, no energy = no checkpoint. If you save sparingly enough, then you will always have a few units of energy to save pretty much anywhere, however the game does a very bad job at telling you when you should create a checkpoint. Initially you'll find a crystal in locations where saving makes sense, which is how it should work, however after not much time you're left on your own in this regard, causing you to potentially save in terrible places or not save after you've been smashed by a falling rock, causing you to repeat a portion of the level.  Speaking of repetition, just like in metroid you'll notice there are a few areas you can't quite reach yet. Most of the times they aren't subtle at all and they serve as a reminder to come back once you unlock the ability required to reach it, which means you are bound to backtrack your steps. Most times those areas are accessible after jumping past various obstacles, which is fine, however it may happen that you go through all obstacles just to discover you need an extra ability just to reach that sweet sweet power up, essentially removing the prize after beating the challenge.  Now, while roaming around and defeating enemies you will eventually be awarded an ability point, which can be used to improve your capabilities. In the definitive edition this system is a tad flawed: the 4th upgrade of the 3rd skill line (yes, the skill tree is made of three lines) is a bonus to an ability you unlock at the end of the game and you must get it in order to access other upgrades in that line, which is a TERRIBLE design choice (this isn't an issue in the normal version of the game). Of course there will be more upgrades for this new ability which will, obviously, be in between the ones you may want, instead of being at the end of the line. Because reasons!  You should buy this game if you don't mind frustrating games.  TLDR: a mix of super meat boy and metroid, visually stunning but frustrating gameplay and bland storyline.

Ori & the Blind Forest is a beautifully crafted platformer meticulously detailed with one of my all-time favourite video game music scores. It teases the player into a mystical and magical forest corrupted by an unknown evil with you controlling a little sprite like creature in its quest to restore natural order.  The game opens up gradually with each ‘level’ granting the player a new ability which allows them to reach previously unlocked regions in the game. Puzzles are well thought out and very challenging at times meaning there are a lot of re-tries until you are able to get it right. Some gamers love this trial & error rinse & repeat style of gameplay and can find much gratification in ‘perfectly’ navigating your weak little sprite through a perilous area (in a similar vein to Super Meat Boy) however other players, like myself, can find such repetition tedious and detrimental to the pacing of the story. All in all if you are a platformer fan, and enjoyed games such as Super Meat Boy you will love this well crafted game. If you aren’t, I still suggest giving it a go but brace yourself for some tedious parts of trial & error resets until you can complete certain sections.
